application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

titleStmt.title: Probing the extreme planetary atmosphere of WASP-12b 2

analytic.title: Probing the extreme planetary atmosphere of WASP-12b 2

abstract.p: 21 We report near-infrared measurements of the terminator region transmission spectrum 22 and dayside emission spectrum of the exoplanet WASP-12b obtained using the HST 23 WFC3 instrument. The disk-average dayside brightness temperature averages about 24 2900 K, peaking to 3200 K around 1.46 µm. We modeled a range of atmospheric cases 25 for both the emission and transmission spectrum and confirm the recent finding by 26 Crossfield et al. (2012b) that there is no evidence for C/O >1 in the atmosphere of 27 WASP-12b. Assuming a physically plausible atmosphere, we find evidence that the 28 presence of a number of molecules is consistent with the data, but the justification for 29 inclusion of these opacity sources based on the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) is 30 marginal. We also find the near-infrared primary eclipse light curve is consistent with 31 small amounts of prolate distortion. As part of the calibration effort for these data, we 32 2 conducted a detailed study of instrument systematics using 65 orbits of WFC3-IR grims 33 observations. The instrument systematics are dominated by detector-related affects, 34 which vary significantly depending on the detector readout mode. The 256×256 subarray 35 observations of WASP-12 produced spectral measurements within 15% of the photon-36 noise limit using a simple calibration approach. Residual systematics are estimated to be 37 ≤70 parts per million. 38

div.p: Among the more than 700 currently confirmed exoplanets, WASP-12b stands out as 40 exceptional. This transiting gas giant, with a mass of 1.39 MJ and a radius of 1.83 RJ, 41 orbits a 6300-K G star with a period of 1.09 days, resulting in an extraordinary level of 42 insolation and, thus, extreme atmospheric heating ( Hebb et al. 2009). Given the close 43 proximity to the stellar primary, this system presents an opportunity to study a planetary 44 atmosphere in a unique environment. The combination of the unusual nature of this 45 system, the relatively bright stellar primary, and the system orientation, which provides 46 both primary and secondary eclipse events, has made this target one of the more 47 extensively observed exoplanet systems. Analysis of these observations has led to several 48 noteworthy results that underscore the unique nature of this planet. For example, 49 WASP-12b is inflated to an unusual degree that could imply significant internal heating 50 ( Ibgui et al. 2010). The atmosphere is likely extended, and the planet may be losing 51 substantial mass through Roche lobe overflow ( Li et al. 2010); there is also evidence 52 supporting the presence of a magnetospheric bow shock ( Llama et al. 2011). The planet 53 has been proposed to be carbon rich, with a C/O ≥1 ( Madhusudhan et al. 2011a), a 54 condition that may reduce TiO and VO abundances (Madhusadhan et al. 2011b). 55 4 stellar primary, probes the emission spectrum of the planet's dayside atmosphere. For 80 these observations, the primary and secondary eclipse measurements were timed to be 81 separated by the minimum possible time feasible with HST with the objective of 82 minimizing any effects due to temporal changes in the exoplanet atmosphere or parent 83 star. After both the primary and secondary eclipse observation sequence, we observed a 84 calibrator star, HD 258439, with two consecutive orbits. Detector-specific configuration 85 information, such as integration time and subarray size, is contained in Table 1. Our 86 choices for the detector readout mode maximized the instrument efficiency and avoided 87 the WFC3 overheads that can reduce significantly the instrument efficiency when 88 observing relatively bright objects, such as transiting exoplanet systems. 89

The near-infrared spectral signatures of transiting exoplanets, for both transmission 90 and emission measurements, require precision measurements; consequently, the potential 91 impact of instrument systematic errors must be considered. A purpose-built instrument, 92 which would eliminate many of these problems, does not yet exist, and the field has to 93 make the best of the instruments available. This underscores the need for careful 94 investigation and a thorough understanding of instrument characteristics. This is best 95 done by a systematic analysis of a large amount of data so that characteristic instrument 96 behavior patterns can be identified. WFC3 is relatively new and an investigation of the 97 instrument is especially timely.

div.head: WFC3 Systematics 99
div.p: Here we report on a detailed investigation of WFC3 instrument systematic errors 100 using a large amount of archival data. Readers primarily interested in the science results 101 can skip to Section 2.3. 102

To characterize the instrument, we analyzed 65 orbits of archive data covering 10 103 objects, using the data from individual non-destructive reads to mitigate the complicating 104 factors of the range of target brightness and the fact that some groups appear to have over 105 6 exposed their targets. We probed the detector system by analysis of both the standard 106 pipeline output and lower level data products (both "_raw" and "_ima" archive file types). 107

We searched for a measurement dependence on the instrument optical state by 108 constructing estimates for focus, spectrum position, and spectrum rotation. The spectral 109 extraction and determination of optical state parameters was performed as described in 110 Swain et al. 2009b. In contrast to NICMOS, in which optical state parameters such as 111 focus and spectral position produced large instrument systematics, we find that the WFC3 112 instrument optical state changes, while measureable, produce negligible systematic 113 changes in the measured spectroscopic flux density. In this regard, we confirm previous 114 findings ( Berta et al. 2011). We attribute this independence of the measured flux density 115 on instrument optical state parameters as likely due to a high level of uniformity in the 116 instrument focal plane array. Thus, small changes in the illumination function do not 117 produce significant changes in the measured flux density. Another area where we see a 118 marked improvement over NICMOS is that, with WFC3, there is less "spacecraft settling" 119 at the beginning of the observations. 120

Analysis of the 65 orbits, using a consistent approach, reveals the way in which the 121 WFC3 detector system responds to light changes with time in the 512×512 and 128×128 122 subarray modes; these changes can occur on intra-orbit, inter-orbit, or visit-to-visit time 123 scales (for details, see Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5 and the Supplementary Information). 124

Importantly, these changes are only clearly detectable by analyzing the individual non-125 destructive reads as the detector is sampled up the ramp during an integration time. There 126 are also significant, systematic changes in the average detector linearity relation due to 127 over-exposure of the array (see Figure 5). Our results are consistent with the WFC37 Instrument Handbook, where the full-well saturation level of the IR channel for science 129 observations is given as ~40,000 DN or 100,000 electrons for the default gain of 2.5 130 electrons per DN. Analysis of the highly saturated HD 189733b observations shows that 131 physical full-well capacity is between ~57,000 and ~60,000, depending on the pixel. 132

Detector-system-related instrument systematics, if not correctly accounted for, have 133 the potential to compromise measurement of an exoplanet spectrum. The 256×256 134 subarray data we analyzed suffered less from most of these problems, which implies the 135 root cause may be connected to the array readout process and not to fundamental detector 136 physics. However, until the root cause of changes in the detector response to light are 137 understood, we caution that any exoplanet spectroscopy observations need to be analyzed 138 at the level of individual non-destructive reads. Our findings summarizing the readout 139 mode and type/extent of detector system systematic are summarized in Table 1 and 140 modes, the ramp effect is minimal and, in some cases, may not be present. In contrast, the 153 512×512 subarray mode ramp feature is larger and more persistent in that it establishes a 154 trend that dominates the data for each block of measurements. During the camera buffer 155 13 dump operation, the array is operated in a charge-flush mode. This charge flush mode 156 interacts with the 512×512 subarray in a way that is qualitatively and quantitatively 157 different from the 256×256 or 128×128 subarray modes. When Earth occultations 158 prevent observing the source, the array is again operated in charge-flush mode. The effect 159 of this is that there is a ramp present at the beginning of the measurements for each orbit. 160

In the case of the 256×256 and 128×128 subarray modes, this ramp is very short, lasting 161 only one or two samples; in the case of the 512×512 subarray modes, the ramp can 162 continue until the next buffer dump and, for the 512×512 subarray, the effect of ~45 min. Recommendation (1) avoids the intra/inter orbit variations in detector function that 174 are seen in the 512×512 subarray mode, improves instrument overhead, and reduces the 175 ramp effect. Recommendation (2) avoids the changes in detector function that can occur 176 during an integration. Recommendation (3) maximizes the instrument throughput by 177 delaying triggering a buffer dump due to the limit imposed by the file index counter. 178
Recommendation number (4) provides a direct way to assess any changes in detector 179 functionality. 180

div.head: Extracting the Spectra of WASP-12b 181
div.p: Due to operation in the 256×256 subarray mode, WASP-12 observations are of such 182 high quality that a simple method can be used to determine the eclipse depth. In the case 183 of both the primary and secondary eclipse, the eclipse light curves are constructed from 184 the Nsamp=2 .ima frame data multiplied by the exposure time of 7.35 seconds. A 185 wavelength calibration based on band filter observations and the WFC3 dispersion 186 relation results in an uncertainty of 5 nm/pixel. The eclipse depth in individual channels 187 is estimated by a joint simultaneous fit to a model light curve and a linear trend in time 188 that spans obits 2 to 5 (see Figures 6 and 7), where the slope of the linear trend and the 189 depth parameters are the free parameters adjusted by the fitting process. The primary 190 eclipse light curve model was generated by a 4-parameter, non-linear, limb-darkening 191 model ( Claret 2000Claret , 2011; the limb-darkening parameters were wavelength independent 192 (for the H-band) and were fixed during the fitting process. The system ephemeris from 193 ( Maciejewski et al. 2011) and stellar parameters were taken from Hebb et al. (2009). We 194 find an offset of 4.7 ± 1.7 minutes with respect to the T0 of a linear ephemeris prediction 195 ( Maciejewski et al. 2011), where the standard deviation of individual spectral channels is 196 ±0.1 minutes. Both the primary and secondary eclipse light curve models were generated 197 using Mandel and Agol (2002) algorithms. We estimated the eclipse depth uncertainty 198 using (1) the uncertainty as estimated by the multi-parameter (Levenberg-Marquadt type) 199 fitting process, (2) the MCMC method, (3) a prayer-bead style residual permutation 200 analysis, (4) and the standard deviation in the mean of the residual time series and find all 201 15 methods give results consistent results for these data (e.g., for the 1.3763-µm channel, the 202 uncertainties for these four methods are 179, 175, 178, and 170 ppm, respectively). 203 An additional correction needs to be considered in the case of WASP-12b. As noted 204

by Crossfield et al. (2012b), the presence of a nearby star, identified as Bergfors-6, 205 introduces an error in the measured eclipse depths. Bergfors-6 is visible in WFC3 narrow 206 band filter images used for our wavelength calibration and detectable as an asymmetry in 207 transverse profile of the WASP-12 system spectrum. Separation of the light from 208 Bergfors-6 from WASP-12 in our WFC3 data is possible, but requires some care. Using 209 the spectroscopy observations of HD 258439, we determined the chromatic point spread 210 function (PSF). The chromatic PSF was the used to fit two components -that of WASP-211 12 and Bergfors-6 -for each spectral channel (see Figure 8). This allowed a 212 determination of the amount of light originating from Bergfors-6 and WASP-12b; both 213 primary and secondary eclipse depths were then corrected, following the method of 214 Kipping & Tinetti (2010), for the Bergfors-6 contamination. 215 To assess the quality of the linear inter-orbit detrending method, we compared the 216 measured noise to the theoretical photon noise as a function of the number of spectral 217 channels averaged to create the time series. This analysis shows that the detector behaves 218 very well in this readout mode; the presence of systemic noise becomes detectable when 219 18 5 or more pixels are averaged together, but the systematic noise averages (see Figure 9) 220 down as pixels to the -0.4 power (-0.5 would be ideal). The signal-to-noise of the final 221 WASP-12b spectrum is increased by averaging together seven individual channels 222 weighted by the uncertainties and achieves about 160 ppm or ~1.15 times photon noise 223 (see Figure 10 and Table 2 For a measurement precision of ~160 ppm, corresponding to averaging 7 pixel-based 230 spectral channels together in these observations, the 256×256 subarray mode delivers 231 nearly ideal noise properties. When the entire 120-pixel passband is averaged together, 232 the measured noise of ~52 ppm is about 1.45 times the theoretical instrument precision 233 (see Figure 9). This is shows that WFC3 IR is a very good instrument for exoplanet 234 characterization. Instrument systematic errors are present, but they average down 235 21 relatively well. Two separate instrument systematics become detectable in the WASP-236 12b data when the entire spectral passband is averaged together. The first of these 237 systematics is an intra-orbit, linear flux change that is easily detrended based on the out-238 of-eclipse data. The second of these systematics is a pattern in the data for each orbit 239 associated with the third (and final) buffer dump; these data have a systematically lower 240 flux value that becomes apparent when averaging the data together for the entire 241 passband. Attempts to decorrelate using the optical state vectors did not work, but an 242 OOT style of approach should prove effective. We did not pursue further correction of 243 this particular systematic because it does not interact with the science related analysis for 244 this paper. Additional observations of both science targets and calibrator stars would 245 benefit our understanding of the ultimate dynamic range capabilities of the instrument. 246

From the point of view of extracting a spectrum of WASP-12b with spectral 247 resolution of Δλ/λ = 42, corresponding to averaging 7 pixel-based spectral channels, the 248 measurement noise budget can be modeled as the root sum of squares of several 249 components. Selecting 1.38 µm for the reference wavelength, we model the uncertainty 250 as 140 ppm due to photon shot noise, 16.5 ppm due to electronics noise, 65 ppm due to a 251 systematic component that is wavelength independent, and 55 ppm due to a systematic 252 that is wavelength dependent and affects the 1.38-1.48 µm channels (see Figure 10). This 253 model is a worst case scenario and assumes the systematic errors have a covariance of 254 zero; if this is not the case, the amplitude of the one or both of the systematic error terms 255 is reduced to accommodate the covariance contribution. Given that (1) a calibration 256 method based on a linear detrending of inter-orbit data results in a measurement error that 257 is within 15% of the theoretical limit, (2) we wish to avoid the debate associated with 258 22 more complex systematic error removal, and (3) our measurement uncertainties 259 incorporate the affect of the small residual systematic errors, we proceed with the science 260 analysis using the calibration based on the simple linear detrending of the inter-orbit data. 261 (see Figure 11 and Table 3).

We explored constraints provided by the spectral time series for the composition of 276 the terminator region atmosphere, the composition and temperature structure of the and VO, along with H 2 -H 2 /He CIA opacity from Borysow et al. 2001Borysow et al. , 2002. We compare 293 emission and transmission models quantitatively using three factors: 294

div.head: The reduced χ 2 ; that is, of χ 2 divided by the total number of data points. Values of 295
div.p: 1 suggest that the model fits are generally within 1-sigma of the data errors. 296 2. The degrees of freedom (DOF), which is the total number of independent pieces 297 of information that can be obtained from the data, as defined by Rodgers 2000. 298 This is not the same as the total number of free parameters. In fact, our definition 299 of DOF often leads to a lesser value than the total number of free parameters, 300

suggesting that not all parameters can be constrained. The DOF is computed from 301 the averaging kernel described in Line et al. 2012. 302 3. The Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), which is the χ 2 + k ln(n). k is the total 303 number of free parameters and n is the total number of data points. When the total 304 number of parameters increase, a better fit can be obtained, which reduces χ 2 ; 305 however, the BIC is penalized for those additional parameters. Models with 306 31

div.head: Dayside Emission 352
div.p: What immediately stands out in the dayside emission spectrum of WASP-12b is the 353 extremely high brightness temperature of this atmosphere. In the near-infrared, the 354 typical brightness temperature is about 2900 K. Figure 12). 360

For the H 2 O/CH 4 /CO/CO 2 opacity-based model, we find abundances consistent with an 361 elemental ratio of C/O<1. We also find no evidence for a temperature inversion (see 362 Figure 13). Our result that the model with the most favorable BIC is based on H 2 363 continuum, with no additional opacity, supports the recent findings by Crossfield et al. 364 (2012b), who argue that more complex models are not supported by the data. If we 365 include opacity due to H 2 O/CH 4 /CO/CO 2 , our results disagree with the finding of 366 with no additional opacity sources has the lowest BIC, implying that more observational data is needed to constrain the presence of additional opacity sources. Molecular abundance and model parameters are listed as inset text for each scenario.

Figure 13: Temperature profiles retrieved for each of the four dayside atmosphere cases listed in Table 4, with case 1 in the upper left location and moving clockwise for the other cases. The solid line is the "best-fit" temperature profile and the two dotted curves are the +/-1 sigma. The dashed curve in the middle is the "median" temperature given all of the degeneracies amongst the temperature parameters and gasses.

figure.head: 98 5 Figure 1 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 1: The WFC3 observation of the WASP-12b primary eclipse (left) and secondary eclipse (right) showing spectral and broad-band light curves as a function of orbital phase. The light curves are based on .flt data (see text for discussion) for orbits 2-5 and have been vertically offset for display clarity. A best fit linear detrending combined with a light curve model are shown (dashed); no data filtering or decorrelation has been applied. The gaps in the data are due to Earth occultations.

figure.head: Figure 2 :Figure 4 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 2: A comparison of detector subarray performance showing the superior performance of the 256×256 subarray. These results are based on comparing the standard deviation of the best orbit for each data set to the photon noise.

figure.head: Figure 5 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 5: The derivative of the detector linearity relation for two sources. We found a characteristic "knee" in this diagnostic when the detector well is filled beyond ~40,000 DN. A complete set of these figures is in the Supplementary information.

163 of charge flush array operation is similar to the effect of ~9 min of charge-flush operation. 164 For future observations of exoplanet systems with WFC3, we suggest the following 165 guidelines. 166 1. Avoid the use of the 512×512 subarray mode. 167 2. Set the integration time so that the detector receives no more than ~40,000 DN 168 before resetting. 169 3. Use a small number of samples up the ramp (for non-spatial scanning 170 observations). 171 4. Work directly with the individual non-destructive read samples in the data 172 reduction process.

figure.head: Figure 6 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 6: The primary eclipse measurements for each spectral channel together with the best fit model shown in blue (left) and model residuals (right).

figure.head: Figure 8 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 8: Left: The WFC3 spectrum WASP-12 includes a contribution from the nearby star Bergfors-6. The WFC3 direct image of WASP-12 clearly shows the fainter object Bergfors-6 located one arcsecond to the West. The contribution from Bergfors-6 to the WASP-12 spectrum is measured by fitting two PSF components to the transverse spectral profile. Right: The measured contribution of Bergfors-6 to the measurements allowing the WASP-12 component to be isolated.

Figure 9: The excellent performance of WFC3 is shown by a comparison of the theoretical photon-limited noise, based on detected photons, and the standard deviation of residuals for the primary eclipse measurements using a single HST orbit centered on orbital phase -0.02 (see Figure 1) as a function of the number of pixel-based spectral channels averaged together. Instrument systematics become detectable when 5 or more pixel-based spectral channels are averaged together. However, these instrument systematic errors average down very well (only slightly worse than the square root of bandwidth) and the ultimate performance of the instrument is ~1.45 times the photon noise for our observations.

262 26 Determining the depth of the primary and secondary eclipse, as a function of 263 wavelength, provides different physical insights into the planetary atmosphere. For the 264 primary eclipse, the depth is a measurement of (Rp/Rs) 2 where Rp is the radius of the 265 planet and Rs is the radius of the parent star. For the secondary eclipse measurement, the 266 depth is the ratio of Fp/(Fs + Fp) ~ Fp/Fs, where Fp is the flux density of the primary and 267 Fs is the flux density of the parent star. In addition to working with these parameters, we 268 find it useful to represent the primary eclipse (transmission) spectrum in units of scale 269 height and the secondary eclipse (emission) spectrum in units of brightness temperature 270 (Figure 10); for calculating the brightness temperature, we use a model for WASP-12 271
Castelli & Kurucz 2003). To provide context, we compare WASP-12b to the only two 272 other hot-Jupiter class planets with near-infrared emission spectra measured with HST 273

figure.head: Figure 11 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 11: (Left) Brightness temperature spectra for the three hot-Jovians with emission spectra measured by HST. (Right) Placing WASP-12 in context.

277 dayside atmosphere, and the spatial distribution of dayside flux density. Interpreting 278 exoplanet spectra via models is the norm in the field. The approaches we used have been 279 discussed in previous work. Specifically, we use two Bayesian retrieval approaches to 280 analyze both the transmission and emission spectra. The first approach, the optimal 281 estimation approach (Lee et al. 2011, Line et al. 2012), determines the best fit 282 compositions and temperatures by minimizing a quadratic (reduced χ 2 ) cost function. To 283 28 determine the uniqueness of the solution, multiple initial composition and temperature 284 guesses are used. To account for non-Gaussian errors (specifically, upper limits), we use 285 the MCMC retrieval approach (Madhusudhan & Seager 2009, Benneke & Seager 2012). 286 The forward model for the emission spectra solves the thermal infrared radiative transfer 287 equation over 90 levels evenly spaced in logP between 30 bars and 1E-6 bars. The 288 transmission forward model solves the limb transmittance radiative transfer equation over 289 45 atmospheric layers evenly spaced in logP between 10 bars and 1E-10 bars. Both 290 models use the HiTemp (Rothman et al. 2010) database for H 2 O, CO, and CO 2 , the STDS 291 database (Wenger et al. 1998) for CH4, and the Sharp & Burrows 2007 database for TiO 292
Madhusudhan et al. (2011a) reporting the C/O>1. 367 32

div.p: lower BICs are preferred. The addition of a model parameter can only be justified 307 if it improves the fit quality more then the penalization from adding that 308 additional parameter. 309

While the primary and secondary eclipse measurements probe separate atmospheric 311 regions and were modeled individually, we used atmospheric "cases" with identical 312 opacity sources for both the primary and secondary eclipse data to provide a uniform 313 basis for comparison. The atmospheric opacity cases span a range from pure H 2 314 continuum opacity to a more physically motivated atmosphere containing H 2 O, CH 4 , CO, 315 CO 2 , TiO, and VO. We consider both the WFC3 measurements and Spitzer photometry 316 measurements ( Madhusudhan et al. 2011a;Cowen et al. 2012), and the atmospheric 317 models (see Figure 12 and 13) are compared on the basis of goodness of fit and the BIC 318 (see Table 4). Two noteworthy conclusions result from comparing the models. First, on 319 the basis of the existing data, we find no support for including opacity sources beyond H 2 320 continuum. Second, even when we include additional molecular opacity, we find no 321 evidence to support a conclusion of C/O >1. If anything, the modeling suggests that the 322 atmosphere is C depleted. 323

We stress that these results are indicational due to the limited spectral coverage 324 available. The modeling shows that an improved understanding of the WASP-12b 325 atmosphere requires spectroscopic observations over a larger range of wavelengths. We 326 explored inclusion of TiH and CrH for opacity sources and find that they can be 327 consistent with the data; this exploration was undertaken using the iterative forward 328 model approach with an implementation described by Tinetti et al. (2007a) and 329 30 subsequently refined in terms of line lists adopted ( Tinetti et al. 2007b, 330 Burrows et al. 2005, Burrows et al. 2002. Although TiH and CrH may be consistent with 331 the WFC3 data, we have not undertaken the detailed thermal-chemical modeling that 332 would justify specific selection of these particular metal hydrides given that other 333 possibilities also exist (Sharp & Burrows, 2007). We also note that inclusion of a model 334 for the atmospheric response may be needed to connect the dayside and terminator 335 regions conditions in a detailed way. Despite these limitations, our preliminary modeling 336 is able to provide some insight into the atmosphere of WASP-12b. What emerges is a 337 picture of an exoplanet atmosphere that is like no other exoplanet characterized with 338 infrared spectroscopy to date. 339

div.head: Terminator Region 340
div.p: The terminator region transmission spectrum of WASP-12b shows maximum opacity 341 at short wavelengths, dropping to a local minimum at 1.3 µm. Additional opacity 342 structure between 1.30 and 1.55 µm is adjacent to the region of minimal opacity between 343
1.56 and 1.64 µm. The opacity slope between 1.1 and 1.3 µm is especially noteworthy. 344

This feature corresponds to about 3 atmospheric scale heights (see Figure 10). While the 345 slope is suggestive of scattering due to dust or aerosols, the slope is too steep to explain 346 in this manner alone. We find that models with H 2 O, TiO, and VO partially explain this 347 feature, while the H 2 continuum and H 2 O/CH 4 /CO/CO 2 models show significant 348 departures from the data in this region (see Figure 12) This is the first time that high fidelity, space-based spectroscopy of a planet this hot 370 has been obtained. The spectra of the terminator and dayside regions are separated by 371

28.4 hours and come as close to taking a spectral "snap-shot" of the planet's atmosphere 372 as is observationally possible with HST. An advantage of temporally closely spaced 373 observations is that they minimize the potential for stellar variations or climate variability 374 in the exoplanet. Although we treated these regions separately in our modeling effort, we 375 were able to find that an H 2 atmosphere, with no additional opacity sources, is the 376 optimal using a BIC criterion. If additional opacity source are present, we find no 377 evidence for C/O>1 and, thus, simultaneously confirm the findings of Crossfield et al. 378 (2012b) and differ from the findings of Madhusudhan et al. (2011a). In cases where 379 additional molecular opacity was added, we found that CO, TiO, and VO tended to have 380 similar abundance solutions for emission and transmission spectra, whereas H 2 O and CH 4 381 tended to have substantially different dayside and terminator abundances; the behavior of 382 CO 2 was in between these two extremes. While the pure H 2 atmosphere is preferred in 383 some sense by the data, a more physically plausible atmosphere is likely to contain some 384 molecules. Our modeling shows that the pressure scale probed by these observations is 385 uncertain and will remain so until the atmospheric composition can be better constrained 386 either through additional data or detailed modeling. 387

The dayside brightness temperature of WASP-12b is sufficiently high that it is the 388 same as the temperature of red dwarf stars of M4V to M5V class and, thus, represents an 389 extreme case of the hot-Jovian class exoplanets. Only two other hot-Jovian type planets 390 have had HST measurements of the near-infrared emission spectrum, and they have 391 36 significantly lower near-IR brightness temperatures than WASP-12b (see Figure 11). 392 Given the extreme nature of the WASP-12b atmosphere, perhaps it is not surprising that 393 opacity due to TiO, VO and also TiH and CrH may be compatible with the data. Because 394 we do not undertake any thermo-chemical modeling, we consider our models to be 395 preliminary and accept they do not provide a complete view of the planet's atmosphere. 396

Opacity due to TiO/VO has been proposed ( Hubeny et al. 2003, Fortney et al. 2008) as a 397 mechanism to produce temperature inversions in hot-Jovian type exoplanets. The 398 currently available data in the near-infrared and mid-infrared, are not sufficient to directly 399 constrain the opacity sources or the C/O ratio. Observations with improved spectral 400 coverage, and higher SNR, would likely provide the needed additional constraints to 401 dramatically improve our ability to understand the WASP-12b atmosphere. 402

The proposed prolate distortion of WASP-12b ( Li et al. 2010) is, in principle, 403 observable in the primary eclipse light curve. The presence of a prolate distortion causes 404 the eclipse depth to be slightly deeper at the edges because the projected area of the 405 planet is increased slightly for angular displacements away from the eclipse center. Using 406

Spitzer primary eclipse measurements, Cowan et al. (2012) found indications of a larger 407 than predicted prolate distortion at measured 4.5 µm. Using our primary eclipse 408 measurements, we searched for the degree of prolate distortion consistent with the data 409 (see Figure 14). Our measurements, at the 95% confidence level, constrain the prolate 410 distortion to be less than 1.34 and are, thus, consistent with the degree of the prolate 411 distortion proposed by Li et al. (2010) and are inconsistent with the large values of 412 prolate distortion found by Cowan et al. (2012). This difference with the Cowen et al. 413 result could be due to probing different regions of the planetary atmosphere. while large degrees of prolate distortion are inconsistent with our measurements. Here, the degree of prolate distortion is measured by the ratio of radii of the planet along the axis pointing to the star, R long , and the radii of the planet perpendicular to the star, R planet .

We present WFC3-IR grism spectroscopy measurements of the dayside and 416 terminator regions of WASP-12b. Our measurements show this is the hottest exoplanet 417 thus characterized to date with a brightness temperature maximum of 3200 K. For both 418 emission and transmission measurements, we find the atmospheric model with the lowest 419 BIC is pure H 2 without additional opacity sources. We have explored more physically 420 realistic model atmospheres containing a range of molecules and find no evidence of 421 C/O>1. This finding supports the results of Crossfield et al. 2012b and differs from the 422 results of Madhusudhan et al. (2011a). We also find that TiH and CrH opacity is 423 consistent with the WFC3 spectrum, suggesting that further investigation into sources of 424 opacity in the atmospheres of very hot giant planets is desirable. From the standpoint of 425 38 temperature and opacity sources, the atmosphere of WASP-12b appears more star like 426 than planet like, confirming that this planet is truly an extreme world. These results, 427 together with previous observational and theoretical work, support the conclusion that 428 hot-Jupiter-type exoplanets are not a uniform class of objects and that these worlds 429 exhibit a diversity that we are only beginning to understand. 430

From an instrumental point of view, this paper reports the first exoplanet emission 431 spectrum measured with the WFC3 instrument. We also conducted a systematic analysis 432 of 65 orbits of WFC3-IR grism spectroscopy observation to characterize instrument 433 systematics. To our knowledge, the scope and detailed level of this instrument analysis is 434 unique in the area of exoplanet spectroscopy. We find that instrument systematics 435 originating in the detector system can vary considerably. The standard pipeline can mask 436 these problems, and we strongly encourage other researchers to analyze WFC3-IR 437 measurements at the individual non-destructive read (Nsamp) level. Notwithstanding the 438 problems with some detector modes, the WFC3 instrument is an excellent tool for 439 exoplanet spectroscopic characterization; when operated in the optimal detector readout 440 mode, WFC3-IR grism spectroscopy delivers nearly photon-noise-limited measurements 441 with a dynamic range of ~6000:1 that do not require complex decorrelation to correct 442 systematic errors. 443

div.p: The research described in this publication was carried out in part at the Jet Propulsion
